resources.string:
char - single byte of data 
int - 32 bit integer 
float - 4 byte floating point number 
double - 8 byte floating point number 
bool - binary true/false value 
void - null value

char - single byte of data 
int - 32 bit integer 
float - 4 byte floating point number 
double - 8 byte floating point number 
bool - binary true/false value 
void - null value
\nPython doesn\'t require you to define variable types\n

char - single byte of data 
int - 32 bit integer 
float - 4 byte floating point number 
double - 8 byte floating point number 
bool - binary true/false value 
void - null value

The main purpose behind the include directive is that it allows libraries of code to be developed which help to ensure that everyone uses the same version of a data layout definition or procedural code throughout a program.

For example in C/C++ we use :
#include <stdio.h>" // This includes the content of the standard header 'stdio.h'.

Within PHP the include directive causes another PHP file to be included and evaluated.

Modern languages such as Java and C# do not use forward declarations, instead identifiers are recognised automatically from source files and read directly form dynamic library symbols, meaning header files are not needed."

= - Using a single equals assigns a value 
 == - Using two equals in succession tests values for equality 
 != - Tests values for inequality 
 * - Multiplication 
 / - Division 
 % - The modulus returns the remainder of a division 
 + - Addition 
 - - Subtraction 
 & - Logical AND 
 ^ - Logical XOR 
 | - Logical OR 
 && - Conditional AND 
 || - Conditional OR 
 ! - Conditional NOT 
 ++ - Increment variable by 1 
 –– - Decrement variable by 1 
 += - Increment variable by n 
 *= - Multiply variable by n 
 -= - Subtract n from a variable 
 > - Greater than 
 < - Less than 
 >= - Greater than or equal to 
 <= - Less than or equal to

+ - Addition 
 - - Subtraction 
 * - Multiplication 
 / - Division 
 % - The modulus returns the remainder of a division 
 ++ - Increment variable by 1 
 –– - Decrement variable by 1 
 == - Using two equals in succession tests values for equality 
 != - Tests values for inequality 
 > - Greater than 
 < - Less than 
 >= - Greater than or equal to 
 <= - Less than or equal to 
 && - Conditional AND 
 || - Conditional OR 
 ! - Conditional NOT 
 & - Binary AND Operator copies a bit to the result if it exists in both operands 
 ^ - Binary XOR Operator copies the bit if it is set in one operand but not both 
 | - Binary AND Operator copies a bit to the result if it exists in both operands 
 ~ - Binary Ones Complement Operator is unary and has the effect of 'flipping' bits 
 << - Binary Left Shift Operator. The left operands value is moved left by the number of bits specified by the right operand 
 >> - Binary Right Shift Operator. The left operands value is moved right by the number of bits specified by the right operand 
 = - Using a single equals assigns a value 
 += - Increment variable by n 
 *= - Multiply variable by n 
 -= - Subtract n from a variable 
 /= - Divides n with a variable 
 <<= - Left shift AND 
 >>= - Right shift AND 
 &= - Bitwise AND 
 ^= = Bitwise exclusive OR 
 |= = Bitwise inclusive OR

+ - Addition 
 - - Subtraction 
 * - Multiplication 
 / - Division 
 ** - Exponent - Performs exponential (power) calculation on operators 
 // - Floor Division - The division of operands where the result is the quotient in which the digits after the decimal point are removed 
 == - Using two equals in succession tests values for equality 
 != - Tests values for inequality 
 <> - Checks if the value of two operands are equal or not, if values are not equal then condition becomes true 
 >= - Greater than or equal to 
 <= - Less than or equal to 
 > - Greater than 
 < - Less than 
 = - Using a single equals assigns a value 
 += - Increment variable by n 
 *= - Multiply variable by n 
 -= - Subtract n from a variable 
 /= - Divides n with a variable 
 %= - Takes the modulus using two operands and assign the result to left operand 
 **= - Performs exponential (power) calculation on operators and assign value to the left operand 
 //= - Performs floor division on operators and assign value to the left operand 
 & - Binary AND Operator copies a bit to the result if it exists in both operands 
 | - Binary OR Operator copies a bit if it exists in either operand 
 ^ - Binary XOR Operator copies the bit if it is set in one operand but not both 
 ~ - Binary Ones Complement Operator is unary and has the effect of 'flipping' bits 
 << - Binary Left Shift Operator. The left operands value is moved left by the number of bits specified by the right operand 
 >> - Binary Right Shift Operator. The left operands value is moved right by the number of bits specified by the right operand 
 and - Logical AND 
 or - Logical OR 
 not - Logical NOT 
 in - Evaluates to true if it finds a variable in the specified sequence and false otherwise 
 not in - Evaluates to true if it does not finds a variable in the specified sequence and false otherwise 
 is - Evaluates to true if the variables on either side of the operator point to the same object and false otherwise 
 in not - Evaluates to false if the variables on either side of the operator point to the same object and true otherwise

+ - Addition 
 - - Subtraction 
 * - Multiplication 
 / - Division 
 % - The modulus returns the remainder of a division 
 ++ - Increment variable by 1 
 –– - Decrement variable by 1 
 == - Using two equals in succession tests values for equality 
 != - Tests values for inequality 
 > - Greater than 
 < - Less than 
 >= - Greater than or equal to 
 <= - Less than or equal to 
 & - Binary AND Operator copies a bit to the result if it exists in both operands 
 | - Binary OR Operator copies a bit if it exists in either operand 
 ^ - Binary XOR Operator copies the bit if it is set in one operand but not both 
 ~ - Binary Ones Complement Operator is unary and has the effect of 'flipping' bits 
 << - Binary Left Shift Operator. The left operands value is moved left by the number of bits specified by the right operand 
 >> - Binary Right Shift Operator. The left operands value is moved right by the number of bits specified by the right operand 
 >>> - Shift right zero fill operator. The left operands value is moved right by the number of bits specified by the right operand and shifted values are filled up with zeros 
 && - Logical AND operator. If both the operands are non-zero, then the condition becomes true 
 || - Logical OR operator. If any of the two operands are non-zero, then the condition becomes true 
 ! - Logical NOT Operator. Use to reverses the logical state of its operand. If a condition is true then Logical NOT operator will be false 
 = - Using a single equals assigns a value 
 += - Increment variable by n 
 *= - Multiply variable by n 
 -= - Subtract n from a variable 
 /= - Divides n with a variable 
 %= - Takes the modulus using two operands and assign the result to left operand 
 <<= - Left shift AND 
 >>= - Right shift AND 
 &= - Bitwise AND 
 ^= = Bitwise exclusive OR 
 |= = Bitwise inclusive OR
\nPython has no definitive switch-case statement. A simple substitute for this is using a string of if-else blocks, with each condition being what would have been the matching case.\n
